Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: I just don't want to become another statistic like her.  If they can kill the President, do you think they're gonna think twice about a two-bit showgirl like me?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: We could call you in, Beverly.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I know the pressure you're under, Beverly.  Don't think I don't.  I understand.

Speaker: price
Dialogue: I saw a man run from this spot and go behind the Book Depository - 30 minutes later I gave this information to the Sheriff.

Speaker: holland
Dialogue: I made it very clear to the Warren people one of the shots came from behind that picket fence.  I heard the report and saw the smoke come out about 6 or 8 feet above the ground, right out from under those trees.  There is no doubt whatsoever in my mind...

Speaker: dodd
Dialogue: ...we, all four of us, all railroad men, standing here, seen about the same thing.  The smoke came from behind the hedge - and a motorcycle policeman dropped his cycle in the street and run up the embankment...

Speaker: holland
Dialogue: ...we came around here to look for tracks.  It rained that morning and we found a bunch of cigarette butts. Someone'd been standing about here...

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: This is a good spot, chief, for the head shot.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: I was standing here next to my friend Mary Mooman, who took the photograph when he was killed...

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: I jumped out in the street and yelled, "Hey Mr. President, look over here, we wanna take your picture."  He looked up and then shots rang out. Mary fell to the ground right away, shouting, "Get down, they're shooting, get down, they're shooting." I knew it but I was moving to get closer to him.  The driver had stopped - I don't know what was wrong with that driver.  And then, out of the corner of my eye, I saw this flash of light, in the bushes and that last shot... just ripped his head off, I mean, blood, brains, just blew everything...

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: I looked up and saw smoke from the Knoll.  And everything was frozen - seemed like people wasn't even breathing, like you're looking at a picture - except this one guy.  I saw this one guy running from the Book Depository towards the railroad tracks.  And that was the same man I saw on TV two days later shooting Oswald.  That was Jack Ruby.  No question about it.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: It was him I was chasing up the Grassy Knoll, thinking our guys had shot back and maybe we got one of them. I don't know what I would have done if I had caught him, but I knew something terrible had happened and somebody had to do something.

Speaker: first agent
Dialogue: Secret Service, ma'am.  You're coming with us.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: Oh no, I'm not.  I don't know you. We gotta catch this shooter - don't you realize?

Speaker: second agent
Dialogue: I said you're coming with us.  I want the pictures in your pocket.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: I don't have any pictures!  I have to go back and find my friend Mary. Lemme alone!

Speaker: first agent
Dialogue: Hush!  Just smile and keep walking.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: How many shots you say you heard?

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: Four to six.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: That's impossible.  You heard echoes ...echoes.  We have three bullets and three shots which came from the Book Depository and that's all we're willing to say.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: No, I saw a guy shooting from over there.  He was behind that fence. What are you going to do about it?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: We have that taken care of.  You only heard three shots and you are not to talk to anyone about this. No one, you hear?

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: He asked me why I thought I was in danger and I said:

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: Well if they can kill the President, they can certainly get me.

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: That doesn't make sense, Mrs. Hill. We have the man that killed the President.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: No, you don't!

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: He kept trying to get me to change my story about the shots.  He was getting hot under the collar, and telling the woman not to write when he wanted.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: Look, do you want the truth, or just what you want me to say?

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: I want the truth.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: The truth is that I heard between four and six shots.  I'm not going to lie for you.

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: ...you heard echoes.

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: No.  I had guns all my life.  I used to go turtle shooting.

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: I realize you're under a great deal of stress .. it's clouded your judgement.

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: Look, we can put you in a mental institution.  We can make you look crazier'n Marguerite Oswald, and everybody knows how crazy she is.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Are you willing to testify, Mrs. Hill?

Speaker: jean hill
Dialogue: Damned right I would.  Somebody's got to tell the truth around here 'cause the Government sure ain't doing it.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: The Zapruder film establishes 3 shots in 5.6 seconds.  Here.  I'm Oswald. Time me.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Go!

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Time?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Between six and seven seconds.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: The key is the second and third shots came right on top of each other, and it takes a minimum 2.3 seconds to recycle this thing.  Blocking the first two shots at the time they occur in the Zapruder film.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Didn't Hoover say something about that?  The leaves had fallen off in November?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: It was a Texas Live Oak, boss.  It sheds it's leaves the first week of March.  You try to hit a moving target at 88 yards through heavy foliage with this cheap 13-dollar sucker, the world's worst shoulder weapon.  No way.  The FBI tried two sets of tests and not one of their sharpshooters could match Oswald's performance.  Not one.  And Oswald was at best a medium shot.  The scope was defective on it, too.  I mean this is the whole essence of the case to me.  The guy couldn't do the shooting.  Nobody could.  And they sold this lemon to the American public.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: The Zapruder film is the proof they didn't count on, Lou.  We gotta get our hands on it.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: That means we gotta subpoena Time- Life on it.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Why not just shoot Kennedy coming up Houston?  There's plenty of time - he's out in the open - a frontal shot?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: I asked myself the same thing.  Common sense.  Even if you miss the first shot, if he accelerates you still got him for a second shot.  No... the only reason for waiting to get him on Elm is you got him in a triangulated crossfire.  You got him on a flat low trajectory from the front at the fence there.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: ...you put a third team there - in that building, on a low floor.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: When Kennedy gets to the kill zone, it's a turkey shoot.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How many men?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: One shooter.  One spotter on a radio. Maybe three teams.  I'd say these were professional riflemen, chief, serious people.  Hunters...  patient. It takes skill to kill with a rifle, that's why there's been no execution of an executive with one in 200 years... "3-2-1...  green!"  Or else "Abort!  Abort!"

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Main Street's over there - the original parade route on the way to the Trade Mart.  Too far right? Impossible shot.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: So they changed the route to bring it this way.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Who do you think changed the parade route?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Beats me.  City officials.  Secret Service.  Dallas police.  They did a dry run with Chief Curry a few days before.  But they didn't bother running through Dealey.  They stopped right there, said something like, "and afterwards there's only the freeway," and went home.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: You know who the mayor was?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Earle Cabell.  And guess who his brother is?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: General Charles Cabell.  Deputy Director of the CIA.  Fired by Kennedy in '61 because of the Bay of Pigs fiasco, he moved back to the Pentagon, called Kennedy a "traitor".  When he came to New Orleans to address the Foreign Policy Association, you know who introduced him?  Our friend Clay Shaw.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: The Warren Commission call him?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: His boss was the one on the Warren Commission who handled all the leads to the intelligence community.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Allen Dulles?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Talk about the fox investigating the chicken coop.  Now we'll have to subpoena them, Lou.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: They're gonna love you, chief.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Maybe we should just call it a day, Lou.  Go home.  While we're still a little behind.  We got two people killed, maybe more we never thought about.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: You never got anyone killed, boss. Their actions killed them years before.  If we stopped now, it'd be even more wrong.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Subpoena them, Lou - Dulles, the Cabells, Time-Life... the whole damned lot of 'em!

Speaker: al
Dialogue: The U.S. Attorney in Washington "declines" to serve our subpoena on Allen Dulles, Charles Cabell, CIA Director Richard Helms, or any FBI agent we named.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, what do you expect from a pig but a grunt.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Without them, it's going to be near impossible, chief, to prove Shaw's connection to the CIA.  We got the same problem with the governors. All of them.  Reagan in California won't give us Brading, Ohio refuses Orville Townsend, Texas on Arcacha, and Nebraska on Sandra Moffet.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: What the hell is going on?  Never before has an extradition request from this office been refused.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: We haven't tried to get Julia Anne Mercer in?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No, she could get hurt.  If you believe what's happening to these other people.

Speaker: numa
Dialogue: She's the best damn witness we have!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I just don't want to do it.  What else?

Speaker: numa
Dialogue: Hate mail here.  Fan mail here.  The bad news is the IRS has just requested an audit on your income from this office.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, maybe that's good news - it was never as good as combat, but this is.  Bill, any more on Oswald and Shaw?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Yeah.  They were seen together in Clinton in early September.  The Civil Rights Movement was running a voter registration drive.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: ...rumor is Shaw, a local boy, was working on some arms deal to discredit the civil rights movement.  No one really knows what they were doing there, but everyone sure saw 'em. They stood out like cottonballs.  I got whites and blacks saw 'em, but last time I checked there was nothing illegal with registering to vote. We still got the Negro junkie, Vernon Bundy, saw 'em talkin' at the seawall near Lake Pontchartrain.  But it's tough, boss - no one wants to talk about Shaw.  He's...

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: You know you keep saying that.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Keep saying what?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: You're not digging.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I think Clinton is a breakthrough. Shaw denies he knows Ferrie or Oswald. Is that right?  It proves he's a liar.  Keep on it, Bill.

Speaker: susie
Dialogue: This is interesting - are you ready for this?  Oswald went to see the FBI two weeks before the assassination.  It seems Special Agent Hosty made three routine visits to his house, supposedly to keep an eye on Marina Oswald.

Speaker: oswald
Dialogue: I want to see Special Agent Hosty.

Speaker: receptionist
Dialogue: I'm sorry, he's not in.  Can someone else help you?

Speaker: oswald
Dialogue: Can I use a pen?

Speaker: susie
Dialogue: But what the note really said no one knows because his boss Shanklin told Hosty...

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Come on guys, think - that's the only reason to destroy it, because if it was any kind of threat, like Hosty said, they would've kept it 'cause it makes their case against the "angry lone nut" stronger! Remember the New Orleans meeting with Agent Quigley the day he got busted?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: ...there again Quigley destroyed the notes of the meeting.  I think we can raise the possibility that Oswald not only was an informant but that he may well have been the original source for the telex we have dated November 17 warning of the Kennedy assassination in Dallas on November

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: William Walter, the night clerk on duty here in the FBI office, gave me a copy of this.  It went all over the country.  Nothing was done, and the motorcade went ahead on schedule - and this wasn't even mentioned in the Warren Report!  Read it, Al.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I have a hunch that from the get go, Oswald had infiltrated this group, probably Cubans or right-wing extremists.  He was at the Book Depository that day, told to be there by their handlers, either to prevent the assassination or to take part in it.  They coulda told him anything, either 1) they were going to close down the plotters that day, or 2) they were going to fake an attack on Kennedy to whip up public opinion against Russia or Cuba and reverse his policies - it doesn't really matter what they told him, 'cause he was under orders, he was a foot soldier.

Speaker: oswald
Dialogue: I can get you in and up there.  This is a shot out the southeast window of the sixth floor.  That floor will be unoccupied between noon and one.

Speaker: bull
Dialogue: What about the elevator?

Speaker: oswald
Dialogue: I can close it off.  The only access is a stairwell.

Speaker: bull
Dialogue: We get them in as an air-conditioning unit.

Speaker: ruby
Dialogue: No.  A floor refurbishing group. Got the van, the uniforms...

Speaker: oswald
Dialogue: He's a dead duck.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: I don't buy it, chief - why would the FBI cover it up?  You're talking the whole FBI here.  A telex that disappears from every single FBI office in the country?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: There's a word - orders.

Speaker: susie
Dialogue: Or a cover up!  Jesus, Bill, don't you have enough proof of the FBI's complicity now?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Maybe I have a little more respect for this country's institutions than you do, Susie.  You tell me how the hell you can keep a conspiracy going between the Mob, the CIA, FBI, and Army Intelligence and who knows what else, when you know you can't even keep a secret in this room between 12 people!  We got leaks everywhere! We're going to trial here!  What the hell do we really got?  Oswald, Ruby, Banister, Ferrie are dead.  Shaw - maybe he's an agent, I don't know, but as a covert operator in my book he's wide open for blackmail 'cause of his homosexuality.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Shaw's our toehold, Bill.  I don't know exactly what he is, where he fits, and I don't care.  I do know he's lying through his teeth and I'm not gonna let go of him!

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: So for those reasons, you're going to trial against Clay Shaw, chief? Well, you're gonna lose!  We should be investigating all our Mafia leads here in New Orleans - Carlos Marcello, Santos Trafficante - I can buy that a hell of a lot easier than the Government.  Ruby's all Mob, knows Oswald, sets him up.  Hoffa - Trafficante - Marcello, they hire some guns and they do Kennedy and maybe the Government doesn't want to open up a whole can o'worms there because it used the Mob to get to Castro.  Y'know, Castro being assassinated sounds pretty wild to John Q.  Citizen.  So they close the book on J.F.K.  It makes sense to me.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I don't doubt their involvement, Bill, but at a low level.  Could the Mob change the parade route, Bill, or eliminate the protection for the President?  Could the Mob send Oswald to Russia and get him back?  Could the Mob get the FBI, the CIA, and the Dallas Police to make a mess of the investigation?  Could the Mob appoint the Warren Commission to cover it up?  Could the Mob wreck the autopsy?  Could the Mob influence the national media to go to sleep? And since when has the Mob used anything but .38's for hits, up close? The Mob wouldn't have the guts or the power for something of this magnitude.  Assassins need payrolls, orders, times, schedules.  This was a military-style ambush from start to finish... a coup d'etat with Lyndon Johnson waiting in the wings.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Oh, now you're saying Lyndon Johnson was involved?  The President of the United States?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I know this, Bill - Lyndon Johnson got $1 billion for his Texas friends, Brown and Root, to dredge Cam Ranh Bay for the military in Vietnam. That's just for openers.

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Boss, are you calling the President a murderer?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: If I'm so far from the truth, why is the FBI bugging our offices?  Why are our witnesses being bought off and murdered?  Why are Federal agencies blocking our extraditions and subpoenas when we were never blocked before?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Maybe 'cause there's some rogue element in the Government!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: With a full-blown conspiracy to cover it up?  Y'ever read your Shakespeare, Bill?

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Julius Caesar:  "Brutus and Cassius, they too are honorable men."  Who killed Caesar?  Twenty, twenty-five Senators.  All it takes is one Judas, Bill - a few people, on the inside, Pentagon, CIA...

Speaker: bill
Dialogue: Jim sighs, saddened.  Bill was one of his best men.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Chief, I've had my doubts about Bill for a long time.  He's fighting everything.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We need him back.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: Bill wasted a goddamn month trying to prove that mob boys like Barding and Jack Ruby played ball in right field with Hunt Oil.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: I don't trust the guy.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: We all need to make room for someone else's ideas, Lou, especially me. Maybe Oswald is what everyone says he is and I'm just plain dumb wrong.

Speaker: al
Dialogue: I've seen him copying files, leaving here late at night.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: I just plain don't trust him anymore.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Maybe you didn't hear what I said. I will not tolerate this infighting among the staff, I warn you that...

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Boss, then I'm afraid I can't continue working with Bill.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Are you giving me an ultimatum, Lou?

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: Well, if that's what you want to call it.  I didn't ever think it would come to this.  I guess I am, boss.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I will not have any damned ultimatums put to me, Lou.  I'll accept your resignation.

Speaker: lou
Dialogue: You sure got it.  You're one stubborn and stupid sonofabitch D.A. and you're making one hell of a mistake!

Speaker: susie
Dialogue: Aren't you being a little hard?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No, I don't think I am, Susie.  Anyone else?

Speaker: mattie
Dialogue: My God!  My God!  What have they done!  It's lynchin' time!

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: I'll get it.  Hello.

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: Hello.  Is this Jim Garrison's daughter?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: Virginia or Elizabeth?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Virginia.

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: Virginia, you're a lucky little girl. Your daddy has entered you in a beauty contest.  Would you like to be in a beauty contest?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: That sounds fun.

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: I need some information from you then.  How old are you?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Six.

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: And how tall are you?

Speaker: newsman 9
Dialogue: To repeat - 39-year-old Martin Luther King, who preached non-violence and won the Nobel Peace Prize, was cut down earlier today by a sniper's bullets while standing on the porch of the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee.  He was surrounded by his closest aides.  The police say they have no suspects at this time.  Mr. King...

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: And you get of from school at 3 every day?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: Do you walk home?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Uh huh.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Who are you talking to?

Speaker: male voice
Dialogue: Okay, Virginia, that's all I need to know.  I'll call you again when it's time for the beauty contest.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Who's this?... Hello?... Hello?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Mama, I'm going to be in a beauty contest!

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: What did he ask you?

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Well, he asked me everything.  He asked me...

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Did you enter Virginia into a beauty contest?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: A man just called.  He asked her everything!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Honey, some crackpot.  Martin Luther King was killed in Memphis today!

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Your daughter's life was just threatened!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Just a crank making phone calls. Happens a dozen times a day at the office.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Our home, Jim!  A kidnapper, a murderer, who knows!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Only cowards make crank calls, sweetheart, nothing is going to happen.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: How do you know?  How do you even know what goes on in this house anymore!  You're too busy making speeches, stirring up every crazed Klansman in Louisiana after us!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Get a hold of yourself.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I'm leaving.  I'm taking the kids and I'm leaving!  I won't stand it anymore.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Honey, come on.  The government wants you to be scared.  They want everybody to be scared to speak out.  They count on it.  But there's nothing to be scared of.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: You and your government!  What's the matter with you?  Don't you have any feelings?  Your daughter!  What kind of man are you?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I'll take them up to my mother's if it'll make you feel better.  Spend a week.  I'll change the locks, the phone lines, I'll even get a bodyguard, all right?  Elizabeth, get a hold of yourself.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Jim, before this Kennedy thing, nothing mattered to you in this life more than your children.  The other night Jasper tried to show you a drawing.  You didn't even notice he was there.  He came to me bawling his little eyes out.  Jim, he's sensitive - he needs more from you.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I promise I'll make more time for Jasper.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Is it such a chore?  I don't understand you.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Damn it, if I say I'll spend more time with him, I'll spend more time with him.  I can't fight you and the world too, Liz.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I'm not fighting you, Jim, I'm just trying to reach you.  You've changed.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Of course, I've changed!  My eyes have opened, and once they're open, believe me, what used to look normal seems insane!  And now King.  Don't you think this has something to do with that?  Can't you see?

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: I don't want to see, goddammit!  I'm tired.  I've had enough!  They say you don't have anything anyway! Everybody in town's talking.  You're ruining this man Shaw's life!  You're attacking him because he's homosexual! Going ahead with this stupid "trial"! Did you ever once stop and consider what he's going through?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's not why I'm attacking him! You don't believe me - all this time you never believed me.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: Oh, I don't know anymore!  I believe there was a conspiracy, but not the government.  I just want to raise our children and live a normal life! I want my life back!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well so do I, goddammit!  So do I! I had a life too, y'know - I had a life, too.  But you just can't bury your head in the sand like some ostrich, goddammit, Elizabeth!  It's not just about you - and your well- being and your two cars and your kitchen and your TV and "I'm jes fine honey."  While our kids grow up into a shithole of lies!  Well, I'm not "fine" about that, I'm angry. My life is fucked, Liz!  And yours is, too!  And if you don't want to support me I can understand that but don't you go start making threats of taking the children away.

Speaker: liz
Dialogue: You never talked to me this way before, Jim Garrison.  I'm not making any threats.  I'm leaving you.  I'm taking the kids to my mother's.  I am - I am.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Go on then, get out!  Go hide someplace.  Join the rest of them! They'll tell you I'm crazy.  You got plenty of people'll tell you Jim Garrison's crazy.  You won't have a problem filing your divorce papers on me ...somebody's got to try, goddammit, somebody!

Speaker: jasper
Dialogue: Are we going away, Daddy?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, it looks like it, Jasper.

Speaker: jasper
Dialogue: Because of Kennedy?  Are the same people gonna kill us, Daddy?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: No, Jasper, nobody's gonna kill us.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: Do you love us?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Yes, of course I do, honey.

Speaker: virginia
Dialogue: No.  I mean like mommy loves us. She really loves us.

Speaker: jasper
Dialogue: I'm scared.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: There's nothing wrong with feeling a little scared, Jasper, Virginia. Telling the truth can be a scary thing.  It scared President Kennedy, but he was a brave man.  If you let yourself be too scared, then you let the bad guys take over the country, don't you - and then everybody gets scared.

Speaker: sidekick
Dialogue: And now, Jerry, here's Big Jim Garrison, District Attorney of New Orleans, Louisiana.

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: Welcome, District Attorney Garrison. May I call you Jim?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: I've been called everything under the sun, Jerry.  Call me whatever you like.

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: First we had your charge that the Cuban exiles killed the President, then the Mob, then you said the oil billionaires did it, then you said the Minutemen and the Ku Klux Klan collaborated to do it, now your latest theory seems to be that the CIA and the FBI and the Pentagon and the White House all combined in some elaborate conspiracy to kill John Kennedy.  Let me ask you, is there anyone besides Lee Harvey Oswald who you think did not conspire to kill the President?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: How many hours do I have to answer that one?  Well let's just say this, Jerry - I've stopped beating my wife.  Or maybe you should ask Lyndon Johnson.  We know he has some answers.

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: There have been a number of reports in reputable news media - Time, Newsweek, our own NBC - that you have gone way beyond the legal means available to a prosecutor, that you've intimidated and drugged witnesses, bribed them, urged them to commit perjury.  What is your response?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Your faith in the veracity of the major media is touching, Jerry.  It indicates that the Age of Innocence is not yet over.  But seriously, Jerry, people aren't interested in Jim Garrison - they want the hard evidence!  They want to know why he was killed and what forces were opposed to...

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: Some people would say you're paranoid.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Well, if I am, why is the Government concealing evidence?

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: Are they?  Why would they?

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: That's exactly my question, Jerry. Maybe I'd better show you some pictures so you can begin to understand what I am talking about.

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: These arrests were photographed minutes after the assassination, and were never shown to the American public.  They show...

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: Pictures like this don't show up on television!

Speaker: jim
Dialogue: Sure they do.  The camera can pick this up.

Speaker: johnson
